questions.question_text: Which is an incorrect syntax for connecting to a source or target database by an Extract or Replicat?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Should be D
B is a correct use case, i think its D that's wrong

choices.C: SOURCEDB sampleDB USERID sampleID PASSWORD samplepword
choices.A: TARGETDB TargetDSN USERID sampleID PASSWORD samplepword

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct, SYSLOG is either in GLOBALS or Manager file - Manager takes precedence over GLOBALS if both have the parameter
according to documentation SYSLOG Valid For GLOBALS, Manager

choices.C: An Extract or Replicat is overriding GLOBALS with SYSLOG WARN.
choices.B: The Manager parameter file contains SYSLOG ALL.
choices.D: The user session running Manager is set to log all messages.
choices.A: The GGSCI session was configured incorrectly.

questions.question_text: Your GLOBALS file contains the parameter SYSLOG NONE, but the system logs contain warnings from the Manager. What could be causing this to occur?

choices.B: It is caused by the thread with the highest thread ID applying barrier transactions.
choices.D: It is caused by barrier transactions in a Coordinated Replicat.
choices.A: It is caused by THREAD and THREADRANGE being used with wildcard MAP statements.
choices.C: It is caused by the use of the MAXTRANSOPS parameter.

questions.question_text: You have an issue where all threads are waiting for a specific transaction to be executed first. What is this issue related to?
Which replication topology requires conflict resolution?

discussion.content: The document sail "(Oracle only) For an integrated Replicat, GROUPTRANSOPS is effective only when the integrated Replicat parameter PARALLELISM is set to 1." So the "A" may not the right answer.

choices.C: The operations for a particular table are pinned to a specific apply server.
choices.A: Operations are grouped into one apply server automatically based on GROUPTRANSOPS.
choices.B: Parallelism for an Integrated Replicat cannot exceed one.
choices.D: The operations are all part of one transaction.

questions.question_text: An integrated Replicat is running with PARALLELISM set to four, yet you discover that for a series of large operations, only one apply server is processing the operations. What is the reason for this issue?
